desc: f(x)=ax+b or there exists t such that |f(1)-f(0)|<|f'(t)|
problem:
\begin{problem*}{}{}
  Let $f \colon [0,1] \to \mathbb{R}$ be a continuous function
  which is differentiable on $(0,1)$.
  Prove that either $f(x) = ax + b$ for all $x \in [0,1]$
  for some constants $a$, $b \in \mathbb{R}$ or there exists
  $t \in (0,1)$ such that $|f(1) - f(0)| < |f'(t)|$.
\end{problem*}
solution:
\begin{soln}
  Suppose $|f(1)-f(0)| \ge |f'(t)|$ for all $t\in (0,1)$.
  Then it suffices to show that $f$ is linear. Note that
  $f$ satisfies the conditions if and only if $-f$ satisfies
  them. So, WLOG assume that $f(0) < f(1)$.

  Fix $t\in (0,1)$ arbitrarily. By LMVT on $(0,t)$, we know
  there exists $c_1\in (0,t)$ such that
  \[
    \frac{f(t)-f(0)}{t-0} = f'(c_1)
  \]
  which implies
  \[
    \left|\frac{f(t)-f(0)}{t}\right|
    = |f'(c_1)| \le |f(1)-f(0)|
  \]
  and hence
  \[
    |f(t)-f(0)| \le |f(1)-f(0)|t
  .\]
  Similarly, by LMVT on $(t, 1)$, we get
  \[
    |f(1)-f(t)| \le |f(1)-f(0)| (1-t)
  .\]
  Adding these two gives
  \begin{align*}
    |f(1)-f(t)| + |f(t)-f(0)| &\le |f(1)-f(0)| \\
    &= |(f(1)-f(t)) - (f(t)-f(0))| \\
    &\le |f(1)-f(t)| + |f(t)-f(0)|
  .\end{align*}
  
  Due to the equality condition of the triangle equality,
  it suggests that $f(t)\in
  (\min\left\{ f(0), f(1)) \right\},
  \max\left\{ f(0),f(1) \right\}) = (f(0),f(1))$.
  Furthermore, the equality condition in the final inequality
  forces the equality to hold in all the preceding inequalities
  which implies
  \[
    \left|\frac{f(t)-f(0)}{t}\right|
    = |f(1)-f(0)|
  \]
  that is
  \[
    f(t)-f(0) = (f(1)-f(0))t
  .\]
  This shows that $f$ is linear on $(0,1)$ and hence,
  by continuity, it is linear on $[0,1]$, as desired.
\end{soln}
